text:
Typing a URL like http://myserver/foo%2Findex.html (which is a valid encoded 
form of foo/index.html), or having an href to it <a href="foo%2Findex.html">... 
both produce a 404 error using apache 2.0.46 and 1.3.27.  [For comparison, the 
same url and href work fine with IIS 5.] Also, for comparison, using %20 to 
encode a space works fine in apache, so it's not clear why %2F for a / does 
not.
creator: kochhar@yahoo.com
nd@perlig.de
text:
Please see the AllowEncodedSlashes directive, introduced in 2.0.46.

But a word anyway: foo%2Findex.html is not identical to foo/index.html, since
the slash character is "reserved" and has a special semantic meaning (http url
path seperator). If you encode it as %2f, it won't be treated as path separator
therefore. So please do not expect a wrong behaviour.

Thanks for using Apache.
